snippet.textDisplay: One hack for making the tape if you don't have the bias tape maker:  Pin a  safety pin to the ironing board.  Finger-press the fabric for the tie and thread it through the safety pin, then pull it through and hit it with the iron as you go.
snippet.textOriginal: One hack for making the tape if you don't have the bias tape maker:  Pin a  safety pin to the ironing board.  Finger-press the fabric for the tie and thread it through the safety pin, then pull it through and hit it with the iron as you go.

snippet.textDisplay: Your pleats should be deeper, so the fabric does not gap at sides, the mask should be fitted as close around your face as possible

snippet.textDisplay: Thanks much this video was a great help and my 1st mask came out close to perfect. I didn't have any pipe cleaner, but I did have some bendable wire I had gotten in the hardware section of the dollar tree. I cut a 4 inch piece then I put it between some masking tape, though I would have preferred using surgical tape since it has material. I  also sewed it with the zigzag to hold it in place and that worked perfectly. I was almost finished at close to 2 am since I started my project late, and on the last 2 inches of  tie #2 ran out of bobbin thread...calling it a night/morning and will finish up when I wake. Thanks again Melanie ! You are awesome !
snippet.textOriginal: Thanks much this video was a great help and my 1st mask came out close to perfect. I didn't have any pipe cleaner, but I did have some bendable wire I had gotten in the hardware section of the dollar tree. I cut a 4 inch piece then I put it between some masking tape, though I would have preferred using surgical tape since it has material. I  also sewed it with the zigzag to hold it in place and that worked perfectly. I was almost finished at close to 2 am since I started my project late, and on the last 2 inches of  tie #2 ran out of bobbin thread...calling it a night/morning and will finish up when I wake. snippet.textDisplay: This is an amazing tutorial. Thank you so very much! I wanted to share with everyone that if, like me, you can't get your hands on a bias tape maker (they're sold out everywhere), you can make one with cardboard that works just as well! I followed the instructions from this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yIY7ldNY8w8 Just adjust her measurements so that you're making the strips to the size you need! Also, Kona rolls are perfect to use for straps and are already pre-cut and measured. Much cheaper and easy to find right now. :-)
snippet.textOriginal: This is an amazing tutorial. Thank you so very much! I wanted to share with everyone that if, like me, you can't get your hands on a bias tape maker (they're sold out everywhere), you can make one with cardboard that works just as well! I followed the instructions from this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yIY7ldNY8w8     Just adjust her measurements so that you're making the strips to the size you need!  Also, Kona rolls are perfect to use for straps and are already pre-cut and measured. Much cheaper and easy to find right now.   :-)

snippet.textDisplay:
Lots of discussion on the best materials the last few days... but I'd just like to emphasize a couple of points:

1) the combination of your fabric/materials MUST BE BREATHABLE. Many videos appear to use fabric that looks way to thick. Hold the layers up to your mouth, if you can't reasonably breathe through the layers - then the wearer will end up breathing around the mask rather than through the mask, thereby significantly diminishing the mask's effectiveness.

2) Seems like most experts are agreeing that 100% cotton is the best fabric for most home made masks; t-shirts and bed sheets (reasonably tightly woven) are getting many recommendations and are readily available. I have had good luck with three layers of well worn/washed cotton sateen sheets. I'm guessing about 600 thread count. Also, the US Surgeon General has a video on how to make a mask out of a cotton t-shirt.

3) As a bonus, you can also use the elastic from a fitted sheet as ties.

4) be very very very cautious of any materials designed for cleaning or other specialty purposes (e.g., vacuum cleaner bags, disposable diapers, microfiber towels, etc...), they may (probably) have hazardous chemicals resulting from the manufacturing or treatment processes.

5) I found the pipe cleaners not quite strong stiff enough for my needs. Paper clips weren't any better. Try standard 16 gauge solid insulated house wiring (just one wire, not the combination of 3 or 4 wires in standard house wiring). It works very well. Just curl the ends back and crimp. It won't rust and the insulation provides a bit of cushion. Often hardware stores have small scraps laying around and will give them away for free.

...

1) the combination of your fabric/materials MUST BE BREATHABLE. Many videos appear to use fabric that looks way to thick.  Hold the layers up to your mouth, if you can't reasonably breathe through the layers - then the wearer will end up breathing around the mask rather than through the mask, thereby significantly diminishing the mask's effectiveness.  

2) Seems like most experts are agreeing that 100% cotton is the best fabric for most home made masks;  t-shirts and bed sheets (reasonably tightly woven) are getting many recommendations and are readily available. I have had good luck with three layers of well worn/washed cotton sateen sheets. I'm guessing about 600 thread count. Also, the US Surgeon General has a video on how to make a mask out of a cotton t-shirt.

3) As a bonus, you can also use the elastic from a fitted sheet as ties.     

4) be very very very cautious of any materials designed for cleaning or other specialty purposes (e.g., vacuum cleaner bags, disposable diapers, microfiber towels, etc...), they may (probably) have hazardous chemicals resulting from the manufacturing or treatment processes.

5) I found the pipe cleaners not quite strong stiff enough for my needs. Paper clips weren't any better.  Try standard 16 gauge solid insulated house wiring (just one wire, not the combination of 3 or 4 wires in standard house wiring).  It works very well.  Just curl the ends back and crimp. It won't rust and the insulation provides a bit of cushion.  Often hardware stores have small scraps laying around and will give them away for free.

snippet.textDisplay:
May I ask a few questions:
What type of fabrics do you use for the mask front, pockets, and for the strips?
Do we use polyester thread with polyester fabric, cotton thread with cotton fabric, etc..?
Is it necessary to wash the fabric before cutting the 6" x 9" piece? (shrinkage)
What kind of filter goes into the pocket?
Regarding the pipe fitter, is it possible to do the zig zag stitch first, then insert the pipe cleaner? (I'm clumsy enough to break a needle)
And a suggestion,
Perhaps use a fork instead of a seam ripper when creating the pleat, to prevent cutting the side of the pocket..?
Thank you!
snippet.textOriginal:

What kind of filter goes into the pocket?
Regarding the pipe fitter, is it possible to do the zig zag stitch first, then insert the pipe cleaner? (I'm clumsy enough to break a needle)  
And a suggestion,

snippet.textDisplay:
Please Forward to all sewers everywhere. I don’t know how to post this on line. Anybody receiving this, please pass it on as you see fit.

I am sewing masks for one person who has had a brain injury and tying strings behind the head is just too hard. I also am sewing for one person who has the use of only one hand, as well as for a number of people with bad shoulder injuries. I don’t have elastic, so I have been using cloth ribbon.

To make a mask that you can put on one handed or which requires tying no strings, or reaching behind the head ( can be used for either pleated or contoured masks):

1. Determine which side is the persons most mobile side.
2. On that side, sew in two button holes on the edge of the mask, top and bottom.
3. On the other side sew in the ends of the ties.
4. Thread ties through button holes.
5. If you can find them, put both ties through a plastic spring toggle such as are used on stuff sacks.
6. Knot ends of ties so they don’t come back out of the toggle.
7. Even if you don’t have a toggle, this allows mask to be put on and adjusted by tying only one set of strings and it is not behind your head so you can see it in a mirror and you are not stretching your shoulders.

Happy sewing and godspeed to all

Doris
snippet.textOriginal:

I also am sewing for one person who has the use of only one hand, as well as for a number of people with bad shoulder injuries. I don’t have elastic, so I have been using cloth ribbon.  

To make a mask that you can put on one handed or which requires tying no strings, or reaching behind the head ( can be used for either pleated or contoured masks):

1. Determine which side is the persons most mobile side. 
2. On that side, sew in two button holes on the edge of the mask, top and bottom. 
3. On the other side sew in the ends of the ties.
4. Thread ties through button holes.
5. If you can find them, put both ties through a plastic spring toggle such as are used on stuff sacks.
6. Knot ends of ties so they don’t come back out of the toggle. 
7. Even if you don’t have a toggle, this allows mask to be put on and adjusted by tying only one set of strings and it is not behind your head so you can see it in a mirror and you are not stretching your shoulders. 

Happy sewing and godspeed to all

Doris

Nurses here are also saying you can use blue shop towels inside pockets to help increase the efficacy, so this pocket version is perfect.
Your smile and helpful attitude have made my day!
Thank you!

snippet.textDisplay:
Having made a few masks (mostly for my nurse daughter and now trying to make some for her coworkers, who don't have sufficient PPE and are being instructed to reuse what they are given...) we discovered larger/deeper pleats/tucks helped to make the mask fit/stay closer on her face. I make a pleat (folds that meet in the center) for the upper portion and a tuck for the bottom.
(My daughter also has a narrow face, so the width needs to be closer to a child's size!)
Also, in contrast with the way you show it (and how I made my first mask) I now make the tucks/pleats along the longer edges, which allows better expansion over the nose & chin. It's a little trickier to sew the elastic, because the elastic is shorter than the fabric, but it works much better.
snippet.textOriginal:
Having made a few masks (mostly for my nurse daughter and now trying to make some for her coworkers, who don't have sufficient PPE and are being instructed to reuse what they are given...) we discovered larger/deeper pleats/tucks helped to make the mask fit/stay closer on her face. I make a pleat (folds that meet in the center) for the upper portion and a tuck for the bottom. 
(My daughter also has a narrow face, so the width needs to be closer to a child's size!) 
Also, in contrast with the way you show it (and how I made my first mask) I now make the tucks/pleats along the longer edges, which allows better expansion over the nose & chin. It's a little trickier to sew the elastic, because the elastic is shorter than the fabric, but it works much better.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Don't lie who's shut down cause of the Corona🏡")Melanie

(ɪ’ᴍ ɢɪғᴛɪɴɢ ᴛᴏ ᴇᴠᴇʀʏᴏɴᴇ ᴡʜᴏ sᴜʙs ᴛᴏ ᴍᴇ)💞
